events.priceDetails: Every Tue, Thu, Fri & Sat - 11.30am.Every Wed - 2.30pm.

events.description: Join a tour of M Shed?s collection stores and encounter treasures from the city?s industrial and maritime past. Tours take place every Tuesday-Saturday.

events.strapline: Can art capture what it is to be human? The Being Human exhibition takes sculptural works by artists grappling with how to express humanity.
events.name: Being Human

events.strapline: From ancient uses of witchcraft, to the role superstition plays in the modern mind, this exhibition looks at how magic has been used to heal, hunt and harm.
events.name: Do you believe in magic?

events.strapline: Your child can join us for a day of artistic fun and achieve an Arts Council England Discover Arts Award along the way! Explore the museum, get creative with and make your own portrait masterpiece.

events.strapline: Discover a millennium of history on this 1.8 mile walk around the heart of Bristol?s old city.
events.priceDetails: The walk is at a gentle pace on level terrain and is suitable for participants of all levels of fitness. Free. Book by calling 0117 352 6600
events.name: Old City

events.strapline: A day of art for Brownies and Cubs! Explore our art galleries, experiment with painting and other techniques, create your own portrait and achieve Arts Council England Discover Arts Award.
events.name: Picture Perfect: Arts Award for Brownies and Cubs

images.title: Picture Perfect: Art Award for Brownies and Cubs
images.name: Picture Perfect: Arts Award for Brownies and Cubs

events.strapline: Many country houses in SW England have historic links to slavery. This talk explores the public history of slavery through the case of Dyrham Park.
events.priceDetails: Free? donations welcome. Entry to M Shed is from 5.45pm
events.name: Slavery, public history and the British country house

images.title: M shed seminar stock image
images.name: Slavery, public history and the British country house

events.strapline: A described tour of the Wildlife Photographer of the Year exhibition aimed at visitors with visual impairments.
events.priceDetails: Free ? donations welcome. Please book in advance.
events.name: Wildlife Photographer of the Year ? described tour

images.title: WPY pengins 2020
images.name: Wildlife Photographer of the Year ? described tour

events.strapline: Join us for a celebration of LGBTQ+ people?s lives, past and present.
events.priceDetails: Free ? donations welcome
events.name: LGBTQ+ History Month

events.strapline: Venture on our guided walk into the once-autonomous township of Redcliffe, where you?ll find some of the most impressive remains of historical Bristol.
events.priceDetails: The walk is at a gentle pace on level terrain and is suitable for participants of all levels of fitness. Pay What You Think. Book by calling 0117 352 6600
events.name: Redcliffe

images.caption:
Redcliffe Hill, Bristol, 19 August 1919. 
Photograph looking along Redcliffe Hill, with the tower of St. Mary Redcliffe church visible in the background. Published by Hardings' (Bristol & Cardiff) 'Progress' Series. Handwriting on reverse.
images.title: BRO 43207/15/214 [MShed]
images.name: Redcliffe

events.strapline: Discover how archaeology and anthropology contribute to our knowledge of human evolution and find out about the latest theories in this ever-changing field.
events.priceDetails: £35 adult. £30 concession
events.name: Becoming Human: exploring fossil evidence for our ancestors

events.strapline: Our expert guides will vividly retell the history of this tragic episode, exploring some of the sites that played a prominent role in the unrest.
events.priceDetails: Free ? donations welcome. Please book in advance by calling 0117 352 6600.
events.name: Bristol's Burning! 1831 Riots

events.strapline: Explore the sites and learn about the causes and consequences of the citywide riots of 1831.
events.priceDetails: Pay what you think. Please book in advance by calling 0117 352 6600.
events.name: Bristol?s Burning! 1831 Riots

events.strapline: Join our expert guides as they take you on a trip into Bristol?s old docklands, Meet you at M Shed information desk 5-10 minutes before the walk is due to begin.
events.name: Floating Harbour

events.strapline: This lecture explores how and why the study of this new area emerged in the second half of the nineteenth century and looks at some of the early pioneers - like the famous garden designer, Gertrude Jekyll
events.name: Inglenooks and old curios

events.strapline: Winter Lecture: this lecture looks at some of the museums that owe their existence to the Arts and Crafts Movement and how interest emerged in the 19th century.
events.priceDetails: Entry is on a first come basis. Priory Road Lecture Theatre,
events.name: Inglenooks and Old Curios - orgins and development of Folk Life collecting

images.title: Blaise
images.name: Inglenooks and Old Curios - orgins and development of Folk Life collecting

events.strapline: Find out about this annual celebration in Japan and the customs around displaying these silk-clad imperial figures with their lacquer furniture.
events.priceDetails: Free ? donations welcome. No need to book.
events.name: Lunchtime Talk: Japanese Dolls Festival

events.strapline: Discover how Bedminster evolved from a rural Somerset town to a bustling industrial suburb and the inevitable impact that this had on public health on this three mile walk.
events.priceDetails: Free. Sign up on the day or book in advance by calling 0117 352 6600.
events.name: Windmill Hill

events.strapline: Drop in and see Hogarth?s vast triptych and learn about its remarkable journey around Bristol since it was painted for St Mary Redcliffe in 1755/56.
events.priceDetails: St Nicholas Church, St Nicholas St, Bristol, BS1 1UE.
events.name: William Hogarth's Alterpiece

events.strapline: This seminar will explore the portrayal of the body in sculpture and how the medium is able to embody the human form, while problematising the male gaze.
events.priceDetails: £10 adult. £8 concession. £5 student and under 25
events.name: Being Human Sculpture Seminar

events.strapline: What is it like to be young in Bristol today? Hear young people from across the city reflecting on their experiences, challenges and hopes for the future.
events.name: 21st Century Kids: Bristol through our eyes

images.title: 21st Century Kids: Bristol through our eyes
images.name: 21st Century Kids: Bristol through our eyes

events.strapline: This talk explores how people across the Severn Estuary have lived with silt, slime and sand over the last five hundred years, and provides historical background on plans for their future management.
events.priceDetails: Free? donations welcome. Drop in. Entry to M Shed is from 5.45pm
events.name: Dreging Up The Past: A slimy history of the Severn Estuary and Bristol Channel

images.title: M shed seminar stock image
images.name: Dreging Up The Past: A slimy history of the Severn Estuary and Bristol Channel
